ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class taught me how to construct a more focused essay. Beforehand, I would often aim too big and attempt to tie together disparate sections of a book in my papers. DS Literature showed me that closely analyzing a specific section of text often yields better results.
I greatly developed and improved my literary analysis, close reading, and writing skills.
Through this course, I developed my ability to analyze and discuss literature in a high-level setting, while also working on my writing skills.
I further developed my skills to read critically and write close readings.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Provide more support for the final week when we read Omeros! I enjoyed ending the year with Walcott's epic, and I think it's place at the end of the syllabus is perfect in that it contains references to many of the books one has already encountered in DS Literature. However, I felt that I did not get as much out of Omeros as I could have, because there were so many passages that I struggled to understand. I know the lack of an annotated version makes this more difficult, but a worksheet with explanations for some of the references would go a long way in improving the reading experience.

This course is very strong, I found it to be immensely enjoyable and I learned a great deal. My one small piece of feedback is that some of the translations for certain texts were controversial. I might recommend that the Directed Studies program consult with experts in the languages of certain texts before instructing students to purchase a certain edition.

I believe that the level of class discussion in this course was very high  I appreciated the occasional guidance from Professor Yeazell as well, through the form of outside materials and guiding questions. I will say that I believe that this course will transfer much better to an in-person setting, because it was often difficult to pay attention during the seminars given their length and complexity.
One strength of the course was the small class size because it was easy to get individualized attention.
One thing that may be helpful is reducing the reading load. Sometimes, it is difficult to fully engage with the text due to the immense amount of reading load.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that overall the use of virtual seminars as a discussion tool was very effective, although I do wish that breakout rooms had been utilized more, because I feel like in other courses they helped me feel as if I was forming bonds with my classmates and having more intensive discussions.

One course practice that would allow for virtual engagement was when the Professor would send emails about a specific question she wanted insight for and in the next class every classmate would share something.
I think the zoom classes and office hours were very efficient. My professor communicated very well through Canvas and kept the students engaged through the online platform.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would certainly recommend this class to another student. This was my favorite syllabus out of all my Directed Studies courses, and I think it includes so many different styles and genres that there is something for everybody to enjoy.

I would recommend Directed Studies to another student without hesitation. It has been one of the greatest intellectual experiences of my life, I cannot say enough about how much I have learned through DS. DS literature is especially close to my hear and has inspired me to shift my area of focus. If you like reading books or desire to understand the history of the great novels and poems of the pat 3000 years, do take this course.

Yes  Professor Yeazell gave great feedback and led fascinating discussion sections, and I really enjoyed the Directed Studies curriculum of books that we explored. The syllabus was quite varied in terms of style, and led us to quite interesting historical and cultural contexts as well.
I would recommend this course to other students because the readings were really interesting and I felt like they had a variety of topics and narrative styles that made it interesting to read.

Yes, I would recommend this course to any other student who is deeply interested in literature or wants to explore with canonical texts in the western culture. It is a highly enriching experience to read all the challenging and enjoyable texts and discuss them with peers in a small seminar.
Yes, directed studies offered me a systematic insight into the Western Canon.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Weekly recorded virtual lectures

Sometimes the Professor would have us enter virtual breakout rooms on Zoom to have discussions. Other times, for essays in particular, the Professor would have us exchange papers with a single person and join a virtual breakout room with them.
recorded lecture and virtual seminar
